reg:regulation.reg:title: Code of Practice for Agricultural Environmental Management
reg:regulation.reg:amsincluded: [Last amended July 15, 2023 by B.C. Reg. 8/2019 and includes amendments by B.C. Reg. 264/2022]

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this code:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Environmental Management Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: includes, subject to paragraph (b),

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: materials that are produced for the purposes of an agricultural operation but are incidental or secondary to the primary product of the agricultural operation,
manure,
soiled animal bedding,
dropped or spoiled feed or silage,
agricultural vegetative debris,
the product of an agricultural composting process,
used mushroom-growing substrate, and
used soilless media, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not include

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: mortalities,
wastes from hatcheries or dairy processing,
digestates from anaerobic digestion,
materials produced or used in accordance with the Organic Matter Recycling Regulation,
soil amendments within the meaning of, and used in accordance with, the Code of Practice for Soil Amendments, or
fish feces;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: agricultural composting process means a process, other than a process conducted in accordance with the requirements of the Organic Matter Recycling Regulation, whereby agricultural by-products, or agricultural by-products mixed with wood residue, are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mixed or layered, and
managed to decompose aerobically with either periodic turning or passive or forced aeration;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: agricultural land base means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a person carries out agricultural operations on a single parcel of land, that parcel;
if a person carries out agricultural operations on more than one parcel of land, whether or not those parcels are adjacent to each other, the combined area of those parcels;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: agricultural operation means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an agricultural operation to which this code applies under section 2 (2) and (2.1);
an associated activity to which this code applies under section 2 (2) and (3);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: agricultural product means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: livestock, poultry and insects,
plants, including trees, and fungi, whether grown in a field or an enclosed space, and
the primary products of a thing referred to in paragraph (a) or (b);
includes, subject to paragraph (b),

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: cuttings and prunings of 7 cm or less in diameter, and leaves, from trimming and pruning activities,
corn cobs, corn husks, straw, stalk, seed hulls and other crop residue from harvest activities, and
weeds, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not include wood residue or other by-products from wood processing;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: animal unit means a live weight of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 455 kg (1 000 lb) of either livestock or poultry, or
any combination of livestock and poultry that equals 455 kg;
means, subject to paragraph (b), plant or plant-based materials that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: have no more than 20% moisture content,
are or come from agricultural vegetative debris, seeds or clean wood, and
have been processed for use in producing energy, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not include materials containing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: coal or petroleum products,
pharmaceutical, medicinal or medical biological materials,
manure, or
paper or paper products;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: capacity, in relation to a boiler or heater, means the maximum rate of energy output from the boiler or heater measured in megawatts of thermal energy;
commercial fertilizer means a chemical mixture manufactured for use as fertilizer that does not contain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: raw or unprocessed manure, or
gypsum or other liming materials;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: composting structure means a structure constructed and used for agricultural composting processes;
confined livestock area means an outdoor area, other than a grazing area, seasonal feeding area or temporary holding area, where livestock are confined by structures or topography;
confined poultry area means an outdoor area, other than a grazing area or seasonal feeding area, where poultry are confined by structures or topography;

contaminated runoff means runoff that contains suspended or dissolved nutrients, pathogens or other substances after contact with agricultural by-products, leachate or other organic matter or pesticides;
drinking water source has the same meaning as in the Drinking Water Protection Act;
equipment includes machinery and vehicles used for the purposes of an agricultural operation;
existing means a structure, confined livestock area, confined poultry area, equipment or a part of any of these, as applicable, that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: was present or operated on the person's agricultural land base before February 28, 2019, and
has not been modified;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: experienced person means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has successfully completed a course in nutrient management planning, offered in British Columbia and approved by a director, and
has at least 4 years'

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: experience in carrying out agricultural operations, or
experience and post-secondary training in agricultural sciences combined;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: feedlot means a confined livestock area in which livestock are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: confined solely for the purpose of growing or finishing, and
fed other than by grazing;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: fertilizer means organic or inorganic material of natural or synthetic origin, other than liming materials, that is added to supply one or more plant nutrients;
fish feces means raw or untreated solid excreta from finfish that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: come from a land-based finfish aquaculture operation, and
do not contain carcasses, skin, bones, guts, scales, blood, fat, oil or grease;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: grazing area means pasture, whether or not confined by structures, or rangeland, where livestock or poultry feed primarily by directly consuming plants growing on the pasture or rangeland;
groundwater means water that naturally occurs below the surface of the ground;
leachate means concentrated liquid originating from agricultural by-products, wood residue or other organic matter;
liquid manure means raw or untreated liquid excreta from livestock or poultry, whether or not it is mixed with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: wastewater, or
animal bedding, feed or other solids;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: livestock means mammals reared or kept for the purposes of an agricultural operation;
manure includes liquid manure and solid manure;
modified means a structure, confined livestock area, confined poultry area, equipment or part, as applicable, used in a person's agricultural operation that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: was present or operated on the person's agricultural land base before February 28, 2019, and
is modified on or after February 28, 2019 in a manner that,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case of a roof and pen structure, increases the total square area of the structure's footprint by 10% or more from its original total square area,
in the case of a confined livestock area or confined poultry area, increases the total square area by 10% or more from its original total square area, or
in the case of any other structure or equipment, other than a boiler or heater, increases its capacity by 10% or more from its original capacity;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: mortalities means livestock or poultry that have died from causes other than slaughter and are not fit for human consumption;

new means a structure, confined livestock area, confined poultry area, equipment or part, as applicable, that was constructed on or first brought to the person's agricultural land base on or after February 28, 2019;
nitrate test means a test for residual levels of nitrates in soil conducted in accordance with section 54 [nitrate test];
nutrient means a chemical element that is essential for the growth or development of livestock, poultry, insects, plants, trees or fungi;
nutrient management plan means a nutrient management plan prepared in accordance with section 57 [preparation of nutrient management plan];
nutrient source means any of the following things that are a source of nitrogen or phosphorus:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: commercial fertilizers and soil conditioners;
agricultural by-products;
mixtures produced using agricultural composting processes;
digestates from anaerobic digestion;
wastewater or irrigation water;
reclaimed water within the meaning of, and treated, provided and used in accordance with, the Municipal Wastewater Regulation;
any materials produced in accordance with the Organic Matter Recycling Regulation;
soil amendments within the meaning of, and used in accordance with, the Code of Practice for Soil Amendments;
fish feces;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: on-ground under-pen storage means the collection and uncontained storage of manure and soiled bedding from fur bearing animals under the animals' pen after the manure and soiled bedding drop from the pen to the ground;
outdoor agricultural composting pile means an agricultural composting process carried out by mixing or layering the components in a pile or windrow rather than in a structure;
particulate matter means the total filterable particulate matter in emissions;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: means, subject to paragraph (b), a structure designed and built for storing, before their use or disposal,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: agricultural by-products or agricultural products,
wood residue, or
natural or synthetic materials used for the purposes of an agricultural operation, whether or not produced by the agricultural operation, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not include equipment used to transport or dispose of, or to apply to land, the things listed in paragraph (a);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: phosphorus test means a test for levels of phosphorus in soil conducted in accordance with section 55 [phosphorus test];
phosphorus-affected area means surface water, or land that is next to or hydraulically connected to surface water, that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is located within the boundaries of an area shown on a map listed in Schedule A [Phosphorus-affected Areas], and
has been, or may be, adversely affected by high phosphorus loading due to the sensitivity of the receiving environment;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: poultry means birds reared or kept for the purposes of an agricultural operation;
precipitation includes rain, snow and hail;
processing waste means solid waste, semi-solid waste and wastewater, as those terms are defined in the Code of Practice for the Slaughter and Poultry Processing Industries;
property boundary means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if an agricultural operation occurs on a single parcel of land, the outside legal boundary of that parcel;
if an agricultural operation occurs on more than one parcel of land, the outside legal boundary of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the combined parcels, in the case of parcels that are adjacent to each other, or
each parcel, in the case of parcels that are not adjacent to any other parcel;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: protective base means a layer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of soil that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is at least 30 cm thick, and
has a saturated hydraulic conductivity that is less than or equal to 10-7 cm/s, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of any material that does not allow leaks or for liquids to soak through;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: qualified professional means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is registered in British Columbia with the person's appropriate professional association, acts under that professional association's code of ethics and is subject to disciplinary action by that professional association, and
through suitable education, experience, accreditation and knowledge may be reasonably relied on to provide advice within the person's area of expertise as it relates to this code;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: runoff means any of the following, if flowing along the surface of the ground:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 179/2021, App. 3, s. 1 (h).]
precipitation;
meltwater from snow, hail or ice;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: seasonal feeding area means an area, other than a confined livestock area, confined poultry area, grazing area or temporary holding area,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: used for forage or other crop production, and
used seasonally for feeding livestock or poultry that are sustained primarily by supplemental feed;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: seasonal high water table means the highest level to which, at any time during a year, the water table below the surface of the ground rises;

self-sealing layer means a layer of soil, or mixed soil and manure, that forms between the manure pack and the underlying soil in a confined livestock area, creating a barrier that does not allow leaks or for liquids to soak through;
semi-solid waste means blood, fat, oil and grease that is separated from processing water;
soil conditioner means organic or inorganic matter that has beneficial effects on the biological, chemical or physical properties of soil;
solid, except in the context of semi-solid waste, means a material that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contains more than 18% solid matter by mass, and
will not flow when piled;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: solid manure means raw or untreated solid excreta from livestock or poultry, whether or not mixed with animal bedding, feed or other solids;
solid waste has the same meaning as in the Code of Practice for the Slaughter and Poultry Processing Industries;
strong, divergent windy conditions means conditions in which wind travels at a speed that enables the wind to pick up and carry dust and solids from agricultural by-products or wood residue;
temporary field storage means the storage of solid agricultural by-products or wood residue outside in a field, but not in a structure, before their use or disposal;
temporary holding area means an outdoor holding area on rangeland where livestock are confined by structures while being collected from a grazing area;
vector means an organism that is capable of transmitting a pathogen from one animal, place or thing to another;
vulnerable aquifer recharge area means land

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that is located within the boundaries of an area shown on a map listed in Schedule B [Vulnerable Aquifer Recharge Areas], and
from which surface water may infiltrate the ground to reach an aquifer that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is, due to the nature of the overlying soil layers, highly or moderately vulnerable to pollution or contamination from the land surface, or
is, or is at risk of being, adversely affected by nitrates;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: wastewater, except in Division 2 [Mortalities and Processing Waste] of Part 7, includes the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: wastewater from flush barns and mushroom growing barns and pads;
wastewater from washing, grading or packaging agricultural products;
milk house wastewater and milk-based waste;
used or recycled water from irrigation or fertigation;
water from equipment, washing or other sources;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: water table means the line between the unsaturated and saturated zones in soil;
watercourse includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an area of land that perennially or intermittently contains surface water, other than

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: puddles,
groundwater and dugout ponds for livestock watering, and
furrows, grassed waterways and other temporary ponded areas that are normally farmed, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drainage ditches that lead to an area described in paragraph (a);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: wood residue means wood or a wood product that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is chipped or ground,
originates from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: wood processing,
the clearing of land, if the majority of the greenery is removed and no soil is present, or
trimming or pruning activities,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has not been treated or coated with chemicals, including preservatives, glues, paints, varnishes, oils or finishing materials,
does not contain a foreign substance harmful to humans, animals or plants when combusted,
has not been exposed to salt water, and
has not been used for or recovered from construction or demolition activities.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Agricultural operations to which this code applies

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of minimizing the introduction of waste into the environment and preventing adverse impacts to the environment and human health, this code requires persons to use environmentally responsible and sustainable agricultural practices when carrying out agricultural operations and associated activities described in subsections (2.1) and (3).
This code applies to a person who carries out an agricultural operation described in subsection (2.1) or an associated activity described in subsection (3)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on an agricultural land base that is not zoned for residential purposes, and
whether or not for a commercial purpose.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), rearing or keeping livestock, poultry or insects, or growing and harvesting agricultural products, is an agricultural operation for the purposes of this code if done for one or more of the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for consumption or use by humans, including as food, fibre or fuel;
for use as animal feed;
for use as breeding stock or to produce seedlings or flowers;
for work or recreational purposes, in the case of livestock or poultry;
for use in landscaping or for ornamental purposes, in the case of plants, including trees.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), if done together with an agricultural operation referred to in subsection (2.1), this code applies to the following activities:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: storing nutrient sources;
storing agricultural by-products that are not a source of nitrogen or phosphorus;
storing the primary products of livestock, poultry, insects, plants and fungi;
carrying out agricultural composting processes;
applying nutrient sources to land;

washing, grading or packaging agricultural products, if carried out on the same agricultural land base as the livestock or poultry were reared or kept or the agricultural products were grown or harvested;
disposing of or incinerating mortalities and processing wastes, if carried out on the same agricultural land base as the livestock or poultry were reared or kept;
operating equipment in relation to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an activity referred to in this subsection, or
other activities in relation to agriculture, other than processing primary products beyond the activities described in paragraph (e).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are not agricultural operations for the purposes of this code:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: aquaculture and activities described in subsection (3) that are carried out in respect of aquaculture;
soil blending operations that bring manure, sand or other materials onto a parcel of land for the purpose of producing soil for use other than on that parcel.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemptions from section 6 (2) and (3) of the Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2) of this section, a person who carries out an agricultural operation is not required to be registered under section 4 of the Waste Discharge Regulation for the purpose of being exempted from section 6 (2) and (3) of the Act.

A person must be registered, and registration must be effective, under section 4 of the Waste Discharge Regulation before using a boiler or heater for the purposes of an agricultural operation unless either of the following provisions of this code applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 4 [deemed registration for use of boiler or heater];
section 5 [no registration required if small capacity or fuelled by electricity].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person holds a permit that authorizes the introduction of waste into the environment in relation to operating a nursery for forest tree seedlings, the permit is replaced by this regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Deemed registration for use of boiler or heater
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person is deemed to be registered under section 4 of the Waste Discharge Regulation, and is subject to that section, if the person was registered on February 27, 2019, under the Code of Agricultural Practice for Waste Management, April 1, 1992, as attached to the Agricultural Waste Control Regulation, B.C. Reg. 131/92, and as it read on that date.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No registration required if small capacity or fuelled by electricity

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is not required to be registered under section 4 of the Waste Discharge Regulation if the person uses only boilers and heaters that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a capacity of 0.15 MW or less, and
are labelled in accordance with any of the following standards, as amended from time to time:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the Canadian Standards Association standard CSA-B415.1-10, "Performance testing of solid-fuel-burning heating appliances";
the United States Environmental Protection Agency standard Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 60,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: §60.5475 Subpart QQQQ, "Standards of Performance for New Residential Hydronic Heaters and Forced-Air Furnaces", or
§60.536 Subpart AAA, "Standards of Performance for New Residential Wood Heaters".

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is not required to be registered under section 4 of the Waste Discharge Regulation if the person uses only boilers and heaters that are fuelled by electricity.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Air contaminants from forced air ventilation
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who carries out an agricultural operation must ensure that emissions of air contaminants from forced air ventilation systems used in the agricultural operation do not enter a watercourse or cross a property boundary.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When odours are not air contaminants
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of paragraph (d) of the definition of "air contaminant" in section 1 (1) of the Act, an odour does not interfere with the normal conduct of business if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the odour is produced in carrying out an agricultural operation in accordance with normal agricultural practices, and

ammonia, sulphur and other harmful compounds associated with the odour do not settle out of the air into a watercourse or across a property boundary at a level that would cause injury, interference, discomfort or damage as described in paragraphs (a) to (c), (e) or (f) of that definition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Division applies to a person who uses a boiler or heater for the purposes of an agricultural operation, whether or not the person is required to be registered under section 4 of the Waste Discharge Regulation.
Despite subsection (1), this Division does not apply to a person who uses a boiler or heater that is fuelled only by electricity.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must use only the following as fuel for a boiler or heater:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: biomass, including biomass that has been compressed, dried and processed into uniform, discrete pellets, pucks, bricks or other units and commonly referred to as manufactured fuel;
natural gas;
propane;
low-sulphur fuel that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: No. 2 heating oil, or
diesel fuel for use in Canada in on-road vehicles;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: biogas, a gas derived from the anaerobic decomposition of organic matter;
landfill gas, a mixture of gases generated by the decomposition of municipal solid waste within the meaning of Part 3 of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses biomass as fuel for a boiler or heater to carry out an agricultural operation must visually assess the opacity of emissions from the boiler or heater at least once each day the boiler or heater is operating, during the period

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that begins at least 60 minutes after the boiler or heater is started, and
that ends when shutdown procedures begin.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a boiler or heater has a capacity of 1 MW or less, the person using the boiler or heater must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that opacity levels do not exceed 20%, and
immediately take corrective action to reduce emissions if the assessment under subsection (1) indicates that the opacity level exceeds or is about to exceed 20%.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a boiler or heater has a capacity of more than 1 MW, the person using the boiler or heater must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that opacity levels do not exceed 10%, and
act in accordance with section 12 [taking corrective action] if the assessment under subsection (1) of this section indicates that the opacity level exceeds or is about to exceed 10%.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If more than one boiler or heater is connected to a single stack and the combined capacity is more than 1 MW, subsection (3) applies.

A person who uses biomass as fuel for a boiler or heater that has a capacity of more than 1 MW to carry out an agricultural operation must test emissions of particulate matter from the boiler or heater as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: testing must be done within 6 months after

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: installing the boiler or heater,
modifying a boiler or heater that had a capacity of 1 MW or less to increase its capacity to more than 1 MW, or
modifying the capacity of a boiler or heater described in subparagraph (i) or (ii) by more than 25%;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: testing must be done during the period that begins on October 1 and that ends on April 30 of the next year,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: within the first year that the boiler or heater is operating, and
every second year afterwards, unless paragraph (a) (ii) or (iii) applies;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: testing must be done when the boiler or heater is fuelled by biomass only and operating

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: under normal operating conditions,
under standard conditions of 20°C, 101.3 kPa dry gas and 8% oxygen, and
at 75% or more of its capacity;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: testing must be done during the period

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that begins at least 60 minutes after the boiler or heater is started, and
that ends when shutdown procedures begin;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless a different method is specified by a director, testing must be done using a method set out in the British Columbia Field Sampling Manual or the British Columbia Environmental Laboratory Manual, as amended from time to time.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person using a boiler or heater must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that particulate matter emission levels do not exceed

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 50 mg/m3, for a boiler or heater that has a capacity of more than 1 MW but equal to or less than 3 MW, or
35 mg/m3, for a boiler or heater that has a capacity of more than 3 MW, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: act in accordance with section 12 [taking corrective action] if testing under subsection (1) of this section indicates that the particulate matter emissions level exceeds or is about to exceed the applicable limit set under paragraph (a) of this subsection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If more than one boiler or heater is connected to a single stack and the combined capacity is more than

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 1 MW, subsection (2) (a) (i) applies, or
3 MW, subsection (2) (a) (ii) applies.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If an opacity limit under section 10 (3) (a) [opacity limits] or a particulate matter emissions limit under section 11 (2) (a) [particulate matter limits] is exceeded, the person using the boiler or heater must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately notify a director;
begin immediately to take corrective action to reduce the opacity level or the emissions to or below the applicable limit;
assess opacity levels or test particulate matter emissions, as applicable,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: immediately on completing the corrective action to confirm that limits are no longer being exceeded,
again within 6 months after corrective action was taken, and
at least once more in the next period that begins on October 1 and that ends on April 30 of the next year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director may impose minimum stack height
bcl:section.bcl:text: A director may set a minimum stack discharge height for a boiler or heater fuelled by biomass, and, if set, the stack discharges from the boiler or heater must be no less than the height set.
A person who uses biomass as fuel for a boiler or heater must keep records and supporting documentation respecting all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the type and quantity of fuel burned by the boiler or heater;
all inspections and maintenance of the boiler or heater;
for each assessment and test conducted under this Part,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date and results of the assessment or test, and
the corrective actions, if any, taken under this Part.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part, setback means the distance between

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a structure or place where an activity is performed for the purposes of an agricultural operation, and
a drinking water source, a watercourse or a property boundary.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, high water mark has the same meaning as in the Riparian Areas Regulation.
For the purpose of measuring a setback, measurements must be taken horizontally from the outer edge or limit of a structure or place where an activity occurs to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a drinking water source

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that is groundwater, the outer edge of the well, reservoir or other structure used to collect the water, or
that is not groundwater, the top of its bank or its high water mark, as applicable;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a watercourse, the top of its bank or its high water mark, as applicable;
the property boundary.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (2), if a setback is to be measured from a diversion point, measurements must be taken in a radius from the outer edge of the end of the pipe or other structure used to pump water out of a watercourse.
