bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite any other provision of this Part and without limiting section 7 of the Waste Discharge Regulation, a director may impose a greater setback than is otherwise required under this Part, or impose a setback where none is otherwise required under this Part, if the director has reason to believe that contaminated runoff, leachate or solids are or may be entering a drinking water source or watercourse, or crossing a property boundary.

A person who, for the purposes of an agricultural operation, performs an activity in relation to which a setback is increased or imposed under subsection (1) must ensure a setback of at least the distance as increased or imposed under that subsection.
In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: high-precipitation area means an area that has, on average, precipitation of 600 mm or more in total during the period that begins on October 1 and that ends on April 30 of the next year;
high-risk area means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a high-precipitation area;
a vulnerable aquifer recharge area;
a phosphorus-affected area;

an area identified by a director as having permanent or usual geographic, topographic, weather-related or other features that present a high risk for adverse impacts on the environment or human health;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: high-risk condition means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: strong, divergent windy conditions;
storm events, or periods of short-term intense or high rainfall;
seasonal high water tables or flooding;
the degree to which a field used for an agricultural operation slopes toward a watercourse, if sufficient to cause contaminated runoff;

a condition identified by a director as having temporary, intermittent or irregular topographic, weather-related or other features that present a high risk for adverse impact on the environment or human health.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (1), a director may identify an area as a high-risk area or a condition as a high-risk condition

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the director's own initiative, or
on application, made in the form and manner required by the director, by a person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Part applies to a person who carries out an agricultural operation in a high-risk area or under conditions that are, or may become, high-risk conditions.
If there is any inconsistency between a provision of this Part and any other provision of this code, the provision of this Part applies.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who is required under this Part to have a protective base must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: maintain the base to prevent leakage and keep a record of all maintenance;
assess the protective base for leakage at least once every 6 months;
take corrective action to stop any leakage found on assessment and prevent further leaks;
for each assessment conducted under paragraph (b), keep a record of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date and results of the assessment, and
the corrective actions taken under paragraph (c), if any.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Permanent storage in vulnerable aquifer recharge areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses a modified or new permanent storage structure in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area must ensure

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that there is a protective base under the storage structure, and
that, if the structure is used to store liquid manure,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the structure is designed by a qualified professional who has considered what is needed to protect aquifers located in the vulnerable aquifer recharge area, and is constructed according to that design,
either

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the structure has a vertical distance of at least 1 m from the bottom of the protective base to the seasonal high water table, or
leak detection measures demonstrate that the structure is not leaking, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person keeps the design plans and a statement signed by the qualified professional indicating that the structure was constructed as designed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses modified or new on-ground under-pen storage in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area must ensure that there is a protective base under the storage.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 23 (1) [permanent storage in vulnerable aquifer recharge areas], a person who began, before February 28, 2019, to store liquid manure in an earthen basin dug into the ground in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a qualified professional assess the storage basin for leaks of stored materials

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: before February 28, 2021, and
until a protective base is installed, at least every 5 years after the last assessment or more often if the qualified professional believes it to be necessary;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if any leaks are found on assessment under paragraph (a),

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: take immediate corrective action to stop the leaks and to prevent further leaks, and
take steps as soon as reasonably practicable to install a protective base on the bottom and sides of the storage basin;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep a record of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date and results of each assessment conducted under paragraph (a), and
all actions taken under paragraph (b), if any;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether or not any leaks are found on assessment under paragraph (a), have a protective base on the bottom and sides of the storage basin before February 28, 2029, or an earlier date required by a director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Temporary field storage and outdoor agricultural composting piles

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses temporary field storage or an outdoor agricultural composting pile in a high-precipitation area must cover the stored materials or the pile during the period that begins on October 1 and that ends on April 1 of the next year.

A person who uses temporary field storage for 2 weeks or more, or an outdoor agricultural composting pile, in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area must not locate the storage or pile directly on or over soil that has a saturated hydraulic conductivity of more than 10-3 cm/s, commonly referred to as coarse-textured soil.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who irrigates land in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area must ensure that the quantity and timing of irrigation does not exceed crop needs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not apply nutrient sources to land

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a high-precipitation area during the period that begins on November 1 and that ends on February 1 of the next year,
during strong, divergent windy conditions, unless the nutrient sources are applied

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: below the soil surface, or
under a crop canopy having a height of at least 8 cm,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: during storm events, or periods of short-term intense or high rainfall, or
during any high-risk conditions that are identified by a director under this Part and are relevant to the application of nutrient sources to land.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not apply nutrient sources, other than wood residue, to land in a high-precipitation area during February, March or October unless both of the following conditions are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the nutrients are needed by, and will be available to, the intended crop;
a risk assessment is made in accordance with subsection (4) before application begins, and the assessment indicates that the risk of contaminated runoff is low.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (2), a person may apply nutrient sources to bare soil in a high-precipitation area in the fall only if all of the following conditions are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a crop is planted before the winter non-growing season begins;
the application is to medium or fine-textured soils with a low risk of leaching;
the nutrients will not enter a watercourse or go below the water table.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must prepare a risk assessment, in writing and in the form and manner required by a director,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for each field to which nutrient sources are to be applied, and
considering the special circumstances of the high-precipitation area and any high-risk conditions.

bcl:section.bcl:hnote: [am. B.C. Regs. 8/2019, App. 3, ss. 1 and 5; 179/2021, App. 3, ss. 8 and 9.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person responsible for a feedlot that will hold 10 animal units or more must comply with all applicable requirements of this section.
If the feedlot is located in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area but not in a high-precipitation area, the feedlot must have a protective base.
If the feedlot is located in a high-precipitation area, any part of the feedlot that is not covered by a roof must have a protective base if the feedlot

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is also located in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area, or
is a new or modified feedlot.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the feedlot is located in either a vulnerable aquifer recharge area or a high-precipitation area, there must be a vertical distance of at least 1.2 m from the bottom of the feedlot's protective base or self-sealing layer to the seasonal high water table.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who buries mortalities, solid waste or semi-solid waste in a burial pit located in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must not bury in a single pit more than 1 tonne of materials, and
must ensure that there is a vertical distance of at least 2 m from the bottom of the pit to either the bedrock or the seasonal high water table.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who carries out an agricultural operation, whether in a high-risk area or not, must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: monitor the agricultural operation for impending high-risk conditions;
assess the effectiveness of existing measures and controls to prevent contaminated runoff, leachate and solids from entering a drinking water source or watercourse, or crossing a property boundary;
if existing measures or controls are inadequate, take corrective action before high-risk conditions materialize.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division applies to a person who stores or uses agricultural by-products for the purposes of an agricultural operation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Allowable storage and use of solid agricultural by-products

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may store and use solid agricultural by-products for the purposes of an agricultural operation only as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: solid agricultural by-products that are produced on the person's agricultural land base may be stored on that agricultural land base;

solid agricultural by-products that are not produced on the person's agricultural land base may be brought onto and stored on the person's agricultural land base only if subsequently used in agricultural operations carried out on that agricultural land base;
solid agricultural by-products may be stored only in a permanent storage structure or as temporary field storage;
manure and bedding from fur bearing animals may be stored in on-ground under-pen storage for no more than 7 months.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may carry out an agricultural composting process using solid agricultural by-products for the purposes of an agricultural operation only as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: solid agricultural by-products that are produced on the person's agricultural land base may be used in an agricultural composting process carried out on that agricultural land base;

solid agricultural by-products that are not produced on the person's agricultural land base may be brought onto the person's agricultural land base and used in an agricultural composting process only if the products of the agricultural composting process are subsequently used in agricultural operations carried out on that agricultural land base.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Allowable storage and use of liquid manure

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may store liquid manure only as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: liquid manure may be stored on a person's agricultural land base only if the liquid manure is subsequently used in agricultural operations carried out on the agricultural land base on which the liquid manure was produced or stored;
subject to subsection (2), liquid manure may be stored only in a permanent storage structure.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In an emergency affecting an agricultural operation, the person responsible for the agricultural operation may store liquid manure in a form of containment that is not a permanent storage structure if all of the following conditions are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person notifies a director immediately of the emergency;

within 5 days of notifying a director of the emergency, the person notifies a director of the person's plan to move the liquid manure to a permanent storage structure, or to apply the liquid manure to land, in a manner that complies with this code;
the person implements the plan in accordance with the notification under paragraph (b) and any directions of, or modifications required by, the director;
the stored liquid manure does not overflow;
the structure is monitored for leaks and corrective action is taken immediately if any leaks are found.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who stores agricultural by-products must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that any leachate generated during storage is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: collected or contained, and
not discharged directly to land or water;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that runoff is diverted away from the storage structure or storage area;
that the storage structure or storage area is maintained so as to prevent contaminated runoff, leachate, wastewater and solids from escaping;
if contaminated runoff, leachate, wastewater or solids escape from storage, they do not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary, or go below the water table;
that air contaminants from stored agricultural by-products do not cross a property boundary;
that agricultural by-products are stored in a manner that will deter the attraction of, and access by, domestic pets, wildlife and vectors.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General requirements for permanent storage structures
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who uses a permanent storage structure must ensure that the structure has sufficient capacity to store agricultural by-products until they are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: applied as a fertilizer or soil conditioner, or
transported away from the agricultural land base.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Permanent storage structures for liquid manure

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who stores liquid manure in a permanent storage structure must ensure that the structure is one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an existing permanent storage structure;
a modified permanent storage structure and the modification was

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: designed by a qualified professional who considered the entire structure and this code, and
constructed according to that design;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a new permanent storage structure that was designed by a qualified professional and constructed according to that design.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who stores liquid manure in a modified or new permanent storage structure must keep the design plans and a statement signed by the qualified professional indicating that the structure was constructed as designed.
A person who stores liquid manure in a permanent storage structure must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the level of stored liquid manure reaches no more than 30 cm below the top of the structure;
that the structure has a protective base;
that the protective base is maintained to prevent leakage;
that the stored liquid manure does not leak from the structure or overflow.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses temporary field storage to store solid agricultural by-products must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that field storage is not located

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in any area in which there is standing water or water-saturated soil, or
on any low-lying area of a field prone to annual seasonal flooding, during the flood season or when flooding is imminent;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that field storage is monitored at least once each week to ensure compliance with this code;
that, before the end of the growing period, but no later than 7 months after storage begins, all field-stored solid agricultural by-products are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: used,
moved to a permanent storage structure, if storage is allowed under section 32 (a) or (b) [allowable storage and use of solid agricultural by-products], or
transported away from the agricultural land base;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that vegetation is grown on the storage location after the field-stored solid agricultural by-products are used, moved or transported in accordance with paragraph (c), either in the current or next growing season;
that, if field storage is for a period of more than 2 weeks, temporary field storage does not occur in the same location again for at least 3 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses temporary field storage must keep a record of all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the type and source of the materials being stored and the date that storage began;
the location of the temporary field storage;
the weekly results of monitoring conducted under subsection (1) (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 34 [general storage requirements], a person who uses on-ground under-pen storage must ensure

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that runoff is diverted away from stored materials, and
that, if contaminated runoff, leachate, solids or agricultural by-products escape from storage, steps are taken immediately to collect and contain them.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses on-ground under-pen storage must keep a record of the steps taken, if any, under subsection (1) (b).

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division applies to a person who carries out an agricultural composting process for the purposes of an agricultural operation, other than to dispose of mortalities and processing wastes.
A person who carries out an agricultural composting process must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that only agricultural by-products and wood residue are used in the agricultural composting process;
that no non-agricultural waste materials are added to the agricultural composting process except as allowed under sections 67 (1), 71 and 72 [mortalities or processing waste];
that any leachate generated during the agricultural composting process is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: collected or contained, and
not discharged directly to land or water;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that runoff is diverted away from the agricultural composting process;
that the agricultural composting process is maintained so as to prevent contaminated runoff, leachate and solids from escaping;
that, if contaminated runoff, leachate or solids escape from the agricultural composting process, they do not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table;
that air contaminants from the agricultural composting process do not cross a property boundary;
that the agricultural composting process will be carried out in a manner that will deter the attraction of, and access by, domestic pets, wildlife and vectors.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who uses a composting structure must ensure both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the structure has a protective base;
that the protective base is maintained to prevent leakage.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements for outdoor agricultural composting piles

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses outdoor agricultural composting piles must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the pile is not located

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in any area in which there is standing water or water-saturated soil, or
on any low-lying area of a field prone to annual seasonal flooding, during the flood season or when flooding is imminent;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the pile is monitored at least once each week to ensure compliance with this code;
that the pile does not remain for a period of more than 12 months;
that no other pile is erected in the same location for at least 3 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses outdoor agricultural composting piles must keep a record of all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the type and source of the materials being composted and the date that composting began;
the location of the pile;
the weekly results of monitoring conducted under subsection (1) (b).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Distribution of manure or agricultural compost

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keeps 5 or more animal units, and
distributes from the person's agricultural land base any manure or product of an agricultural composting process that was produced on that agricultural land base.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who distributes manure or the product of an agricultural composting process in units of 5 m3 or less must keep an annual record of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total amount distributed, expressed in m3;
the dates that distribution began and ended;
the type of agricultural by-product distributed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who distributes manure or the product of an agricultural composting process in units of more than 5 m3 must keep, for each distribution, a receipt that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is signed by the receiver, and
shows all of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the amount distributed, expressed in m3;
the date of distribution;
the type of agricultural by-product distributed;
the name and business contact information of the receiver.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who distributes a product resulting from an agricultural composting process must not describe the product as "compost" or "composted".

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Allowable storage and use of other nutrient sources

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a person may do one or both of the following, but only if the nutrient sources are subsequently used in agricultural operations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bring nutrient sources onto the person's agricultural land base;
store nutrient sources on the person's agricultural land base.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to the following types of nutrient sources:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: commercial fertilizers and soil conditioners;
agricultural by-products.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General storage requirements for other nutrient sources
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who stores nutrient sources to which section 43.1 applies must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that any leachate generated during storage is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: collected or contained, and
not discharged directly to land or water;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that runoff is diverted away from the storage structure or storage area;
that the storage structure or storage area is maintained so as to prevent contaminated runoff, leachate, wastewater and solids from escaping;
that if contaminated runoff, leachate, wastewater or solids escape from storage, they do not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table;
that air contaminants from stored nutrient sources do not cross a property boundary;
that nutrient sources are stored in a manner that will deter the attraction of, and access by, domestic pets, wildlife and vectors.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division applies to a person who collects, stores or uses wood residue for the purposes of an agricultural operation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Allowable storage and use of wood residue
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person may do one or both of the following, but only if the wood residue is subsequently used in agricultural operations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bring wood residue onto the person's agricultural land base;
store wood residue on the person's agricultural land base

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in a permanent storage structure, or
as temporary field storage for a period of no more than 12 months.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General storage and land application requirements
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who stores wood residue or applies wood residue to land must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that storage is not located, or wood residue is not applied to land,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in any area in which there is standing water or water-saturated soil, or
on any low-lying area of a field prone to annual seasonal flooding, during the flood season or when flooding is imminent;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that wood residue, contaminated runoff, leachate, solids and dust do not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table;
in the case of storage,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that leachate does not escape from the storage, and
that runoff is diverted away from the storage.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not use wood residue

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the construction of berms,
as an envelope for tile drains,
as fill or to level a site,
to create an access way through a watercourse, or
for any other purpose, other than a purpose referred to in subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless it would contravene subsection (1) (a) to (d), a person may use wood residue for the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as plant mulch or for horticultural bedding;
as soil conditioner or ground cover;
as a component of growing media;
as a component of compost;
in confined livestock areas or confined poultry areas, or in areas where livestock and poultry are exercised;
as animal bedding;
to create an access way on an agricultural land base;
as fuel for wood-fired boilers.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division applies to a person who applies nutrient sources for the purposes of an agricultural operation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not apply nutrient sources to land

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on which there is standing water or water-saturated soil,
on ground in which the top 5 cm of soil is frozen so as to be impenetrable to manually-operated equipment,
on a field having at least 5 cm of ice or snow over at least 50% of its area, or

at a rate of application, under meteorological, topographical or soil conditions, or in a manner, that may cause nutrient sources or contaminated runoff, leachate or solids to enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not apply to land a material described in any of paragraphs (e) to (g) of the definition of "nutrient source" unless the material is treated, provided, used or produced, as applicable, in accordance with this code and the applicable regulation referred to in those paragraphs.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prohibitions on applying compost to land

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, foreign matter

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: means, subject to paragraph (b), a contaminant that does not readily decompose during an agricultural composting process, and
does not include silt, sand, rocks or stones, gravel less than 2.5 cm in diameter, or other mineral materials naturally found in soil.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not apply to land the product of an agricultural composting process, or compost processed in accordance with the Organic Matter Recycling Regulation, if the product or compost contains any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: animal flesh, or bones with visible flesh attached;
more than 1% foreign matter by dry weight;
any sharp foreign matter in a size or shape that could cause injury to a person who or an animal that comes into contact with it.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General requirements for applications to land

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who applies nutrient sources to land must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that nutrient sources and leachate produced by nutrient sources do not escape during transportation or piping;
that nutrient sources are not discharged or applied directly into a watercourse, across a property boundary or below the water table;
that drift from nutrient sources sprayed onto land does not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table;

that the total amount of available nitrogen in the soil, if applicable, and from all nutrient sources applied in one year of application, is equal to or less than the amount of nitrogen needed for optimum crop growth and yield.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who applies nutrient sources to land, other than land that is part of an agricultural operation having an agricultural land base totalling less than 2 ha, must make and keep records of all of the following in respect of each field to which the nutrient sources are applied:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the location and size of the field;
the crop nutrient requirements of the field;
the crop yields of the field;
the date and location of each application of nutrients;
whether the nutrient sources were solids or liquids and the type of nutrient sources applied;
the calculated nutrient application rate;
the rate at which nutrients were actually applied;
the results of testing conducted under section 53 [requirement to test soil].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General requirements for applications other than to land

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who applies nutrient sources to a crop but not to land must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that nutrient sources and leachate produced by nutrient sources do not escape during transportation or piping;
that, in the case of nutrient sources applied to crops in containers,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: nutrient sources are not discharged or applied directly into a watercourse, across a property boundary or below the water table, and
contaminated runoff, leachate, solids or drift from sprayed nutrient sources does not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the total amount of available nitrogen from all nutrient sources applied in one year of application is equal to or less than the amount of nitrogen needed for optimum crop growth and yield.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who applies nutrient sources to a crop but not to land must make and keep records of all of the following in respect of each crop to which nutrient sources are applied:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the crop nutrient requirements;
the calculated nutrient application rate;
whether the nutrient sources were solids or liquids and the type of nutrient sources applied.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a person who applies nutrient sources to land must have the soil in each field tested as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the result of a nitrate test for the field is 100 kg N/ha or more, a nitrate test must be conducted again for that field the following year;
if paragraph (a) does not apply, a nitrate test must be conducted at least once every 3 years;
a phosphorus test must be conducted at least once every 3 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply if the land to which nutrient sources are being applied

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is part of an agricultural operation having an agricultural land base totalling less than 2 ha,
is used to grow crops that are intentionally flooded for harvest, or
is composed of organic soils commonly referred to as peat or muck soils.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A nitrate test must be conducted in accordance with one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a post-harvest nitrate test that measures the amount of nitrate-nitrogen left in soil and not used by the most recently harvested crop must be conducted

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: using a representative sample, and
after the last harvest of the growing season but before the autumn rains typically begin;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a test equivalent to a post-harvest nitrate test that will produce results representative of the amount of nitrate-nitrogen left in soil and not used by the most recently harvested crop.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A phosphorus test must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: measure the amount of available phosphorus in soil, and
be conducted using a representative sample.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If phosphorus test results are obtained using a method other than that commonly referred to as the "Kelowna method", the results must be converted to a value that is equivalent to the results that would have been obtained if the Kelowna method had been used.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When nutrient management plan is required

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 58 [exemptions or modifications to nutrient management plans], a person who applies nutrient sources to a field must have a nutrient management plan if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the result of a nitrate test for the field is 100 kg N/ha or more, and
the conditions of any of subsections (2) to (4) are met.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of subsection (1) (b), a nutrient management plan is required if the field is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: part of an agricultural operation having an agricultural land base totalling 5 ha or more, and
located in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area shown on Map B1, as listed in Schedule B.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of subsection (1) (b), a nutrient management plan is required if the field is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: part of an agricultural operation having an agricultural land base totalling 5 ha or more,
located in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area shown on a map having a number beginning with "B2", "B3" or "B4", as listed in Schedule B, and
used for agricultural operations involving livestock or poultry.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of subsection (1) (b), a nutrient management plan is required if the field is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: part of an agricultural operation having an agricultural land base totalling 30 ha or more,
located in a vulnerable aquifer recharge area shown on a map having a number beginning with "B2", "B3" or "B4", as listed in Schedule B, and
used for agricultural operations involving no livestock or poultry.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A nutrient management plan must be prepared

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by a qualified professional who has successfully completed a course in nutrient management planning, offered in British Columbia and approved by a director, if the result referred to in section 56 (c) [when nutrient management plan is required] is 150 kg N/ha or more, and
by an experienced person, in any other case.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who prepares a nutrient management plan must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consider all nutrient sources available to the crop, including nutrients in the soil and nutrients applied to and removed from a field, and
design the plan to achieve the following objectives:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to minimize the risk of nitrogen and phosphorus loss from a field to the environment;
to achieve an agronomic nitrogen balance of 0 for a field.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who prepares a nutrient management plan must sign and date the completed plan.

bcl:section.bcl:hnote: [am. B.C. Reg. 179/2021, App. 3, s. 19 and App. 4, s. 2.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemptions or modifications to nutrient management plans

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may apply to a director, in the form and manner required by the director, for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an exemption from the requirement to have a nutrient management plan, or
a modification of a requirement of section 57 [preparation of nutrient management plan].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may grant an exemption or a modification if satisfied that the exemption or modification

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is necessary because

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: soil test results under section 53 [requirements to test soil] are unusually high due to a meteorological or other natural event, or
the person cannot comply with the requirement because no qualified professional, as described in section 57 (1) (a), or experienced person, as applicable, is reasonably available to the person, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: will not jeopardize the achievement of the purposes of this code, as stated under section 2 (1) [agricultural operations to which this code applies].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may grant an exemption or a modification

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with or without conditions, and
for a period of up to one year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is granted an exemption or modification under this section must comply with all conditions, if any, imposed under subsection (3) (a).
A person who must have a nutrient management plan must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the plan is prepared by a qualified professional, notify a director, in the form and manner required by the director, that a plan has been made or revised;
implement the plan;

keep a copy of the plan, the information on which it is based, including information from records made under section 51 (2) [general requirements for applications to land], and of any changes made to the plan, and make and keep records to demonstrate compliance with the plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who must have a nutrient management plan prepared must do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: review the plan at least once each year;
if no significant change has been made to the person's agricultural operation within the year, make any necessary changes identified by the review.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On making any significant change to the person's agricultural operations, a person who must have a nutrient management plan prepared must have a qualified professional or experienced person, as applicable under and in compliance with section 57 [preparation of nutrient management plan],

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: review the plan and make any necessary changes identified by the review, and
sign and date the plan on completing the review and any changes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A nutrient management plan expires 5 years after the later of the dates referred to in section 57 (3) and subsection 3 (b) of this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's powers respecting application of nutrient sources

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite any other provision of this Division, a director may do one or more of the following if the director has reason to believe that the application of nutrient sources is or may be having an adverse impact on the environment or human health:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prohibit the application of nutrient sources in one or more areas

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: during a specified period, and
until soil testing, water quality monitoring or other testing indicates that the prohibition is not needed to protect the environment or human health;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require a person to have a qualified professional, as described in section 57 (1) (a), or an experienced person prepare or change a nutrient management plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not contravene a prohibition made under subsection (1) (a).
A person who is subject to a requirement under subsection (1) (b) must comply with the requirement.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division applies to a person who keeps livestock or poultry for the purposes of an agricultural operation.
A person responsible for a confined livestock area or confined poultry area must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that livestock and poultry do not have direct access to a drinking water source or watercourse;
that contaminated runoff, leachate, solids and air contaminants do not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table;
that the accumulation of manure, animal bedding and feed within the area is managed so as to prevent contaminated runoff, leachate and solids from escaping;
that if contaminated runoff, leachate or solids escape from the area, they are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: collected and contained, and
not discharged directly to land or water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person responsible for a feedlot must ensure both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the self-sealing layer that forms under the feedlot is maintained so as to prevent leachate from entering groundwater;
that runoff is diverted away from the feedlot.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person responsible for a feedlot that will no longer be used must decommission the feedlot by removing the manure pack that accumulated over the self-sealing layer and cleaning out the pens in a manner that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prevents leachate from entering groundwater or a watercourse, and
allows nutrients from the manure to be stored and applied to land in accordance with this code.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Seasonal feeding, grazing and temporary holding areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person responsible for a grazing area, seasonal feeding area or temporary holding area in which livestock or poultry have direct access to a watercourse must ensure that effective controls are in place to minimize

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: trampling and erosion of soil into the watercourse, and
contaminated runoff, leachate and solids entering the watercourse.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person responsible for a grazing area must move livestock

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: from areas that are flooded or where flooding is imminent, and
during the flood season from areas that are prone to annual seasonal flooding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person responsible for a seasonal feeding area must ensure that, while livestock are present, on-ground feeding locations and mobile feeding bins are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not located

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in areas that are flooded or where flooding is imminent, or
during the flood season in areas that are prone to annual seasonal flooding, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: distributed evenly over the seasonal feeding area, in a manner that prevents the accumulation of manure near feeding locations or bins.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person responsible for a temporary holding area must ensure that livestock or poultry are not held in the temporary holding area for a period of more than 72 hours.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who keeps 5 or more animal units must make and keep records of all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total number of animals;

the total amount of manure, including bedding mixed with the manure, collected annually, expressed in m3, and divided according to the type of animal the manure is from and whether the manure is liquid or solid;
the amount of manure, expressed in m3, managed by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: distribution in accordance with section 43 [distribution of manure or agricultural compost], or
application as fertilizer or a soil conditioner in accordance with Division 4 [Nutrient Application and Management] of Part 6.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), this Division applies to a person who does any of the following for the purposes of an agricultural operation:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: stores, transports or disposes of mortalities or processing waste, other than transporting mortalities and processing waste to a facility or place regulated under another enactment for the purpose of disposal;
applies wastewater, within the meaning of the Code of Practice for the Slaughter and Poultry Processing Industries, to land.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Division does not apply to a person who disposes of multiple mortalities totalling 5 tonnes or more that died during a single event of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fire, flood or other disaster, or
disease outbreak.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the limits set out in this section, a person may dispose of mortalities or processing waste on the person's agricultural land base by adding the mortalities or processing waste to an agricultural composting process or by burial or incineration.
A person may dispose only of mortalities that died on the person's agricultural land base.
A person may dispose only of processing waste that comes from livestock or poultry that were reared, kept or slaughtered on the person's agricultural land base.
A person must not dispose, in a year, of processing waste that comes from the slaughter of 5 tonnes or more of livestock or 1.5 tonnes or more of poultry, determined on a live weight basis.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who carries out an activity to which this Division applies must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that mortalities are not disposed of into, and are prevented from entering, a watercourse;
that, if a mortality enters a watercourse, the owner of the mortality removes that mortality immediately;
that processing waste does not enter a watercourse;
that contaminated runoff, leachate, solids and air contaminants from the activity do not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table;
that odours and particulate matter from the activity are minimized;
that the activity will be carried out in a manner that will deter the attraction of, and access by, domestic pets, wildlife and vectors.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who stores mortalities must ensure that the mortalities are stored in a manner that prevents

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: putrefaction, and
leachate from escaping.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may store processing waste and leachate on an agricultural land base only in a structure

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that is completely enclosed, and
from which the processing waste and leachate cannot escape.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person may transport mortalities and processing waste from an agricultural land base only in containers from which the mortalities and processing waste, and leachate from them, cannot escape.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who disposes of mortalities or processing waste by adding the mortalities or processing waste to an agricultural composting process must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that composting occurs only in a composting structure or in an outdoor agricultural composting pile;
that contaminated runoff, leachate and solids from the compost do not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table;
that air contaminants from the compost do not cross a property boundary;
that composting will be carried out in a manner that will deter the attraction of, and access by, domestic pets, wildlife and vectors.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 179/2021, App. 3, s. 24 (b).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not dispose of more than 5 tonnes of mortalities or processing waste by adding the mortalities or processing waste to an agricultural composting process in any 30-day period unless the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notifies a director immediately on becoming aware that disposal is necessary and before disposal occurs, and
complies with the requirements, if any, imposed by the director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who disposes of mortalities or processing waste by adding the mortalities or processing waste to an agricultural composting process must keep a record of all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the type and source of the mortalities or processing waste being composted;
whether any of the mortalities or processing waste being composted contains specified risk material within the meaning of the Code of Practice for the Slaughter and Poultry Processing Industries.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses an outdoor agricultural composting pile to dispose of mortalities or processing waste through agricultural composting processes must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the pile is not located

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in any area in which there is standing water or water-saturated soil, or
on any low-lying area of a field prone to annual seasonal flooding;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the pile does not remain for a period of more than 15 months;
that no other pile is erected in the same location for at least 3 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who uses an outdoor agricultural composting pile to dispose of mortalities or processing waste through an agricultural composting process must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: monitor the pile at least once each week to ensure compliance with this code;
keep a record of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the location of the pile,
the date the pile was formed, and
the results of weekly monitoring under paragraph (a).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Land applications of wastewater and agricultural compost

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, the following terms have the same meaning as in the Code of Practice for the Slaughter and Poultry Processing Industries:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specified risk material;
wastewater.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who applies wastewater to land must ensure that the wastewater

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contains no solid waste or visible tissue,
is applied only on the agricultural land base on which the wastewater was generated, and
is not applied to land used to grow crops for human consumption or to graze domestic ruminants, if the wastewater contains specified risk material.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who applies wastewater to land must comply with Division 4 [Nutrient Application and Management] of Part 6 as if the person were applying nutrient sources to the land.
A person who applies the product of an agricultural composting process to land must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that, if the product contains specified risk material, the product is not applied to land used to grow crops for human consumption or to graze domestic ruminants;
that composted mortalities and processing waste are applied to land only when fully composted;
that composted mortalities and processing waste from livestock are applied to land only on, and are not removed from, the agricultural land base on which the composting occurred;
that composted mortalities and processing waste from poultry are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: applied to land only on, and are not removed from, the agricultural land base on which the composting occurred, or
removed from the agricultural land base on which the composting occurred only if the composted mortalities and processing waste

bcl:clause.bcl:text: are first mixed with poultry manure, and
form no more than 10% of the total volume of the mixture.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who applies wastewater or the product of an agricultural composting process to land must keep a record of all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the location of the fields to which the wastewater or product was applied;
the date of the application;
whether any of the applied wastewater or products contain specified risk material and, if so, the location of the fields to which that wastewater or those products have been applied.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who buries mortalities, solid waste or semi-solid waste must ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that no more than 2.5 tonnes are buried in a single burial pit;
that burial pits are not located

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: closer than 60 m apart, unless each pit has been unused for at least 10 years,
in or over soil that has a saturated hydraulic conductivity of more than 10-3 cm/s, commonly referred to as coarse-textured soil,
in, or in the vicinity of, unstable soils that might cause the buried materials to escape the burial pit,
in any area in which there is standing water or water-saturated soil,
in any low-lying area of a field prone to annual seasonal flooding, or
in a field within a 200-year flood plain;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that there is a vertical distance of at least 1.5 m from the bottom of the pit to either the bedrock or the seasonal high water table;
that buried materials are covered immediately after burial with at least 0.6 m of soil.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who closes a burial pit must ensure that the pit is covered with at least 1 m of soil that is compacted and mounded in a manner that will

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: minimize the percolation of precipitation into the pit,
divert runoff away from the pit, and
deter the attraction of, and access by, domestic pets, wildlife and vectors.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who buries mortalities, solid waste or semi-solid waste must make and keep records of all of the following in respect of each burial pit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the location of the pit;
the type and amount, expressed in tonnes, of materials buried;
the date the pit is closed, if applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who incinerates mortalities, solid waste or semi-solid waste must ensure that the incinerator is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: designed and manufactured specifically for the incineration of mortalities, and

designed such that emissions of particulate matter from the incinerator, determined under standard conditions of an O2 reference level of 11%, at 25°C and 101.3 kPa, do not exceed the following limits:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for an existing incinerator, 180 mg/m3;
for a new incinerator that has a chamber capacity of

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who incinerates mortalities, solid waste or semi-solid waste must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: visually assess the opacity of emissions from the incinerator at least once

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: every 12 hours, and
during each burn cycle, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately take corrective action to reduce the opacity level to or below the following limit, as applicable, if the assessment indicates that the opacity level exceeds that limit:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 20%, for

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a new incinerator that has a chamber capacity of less than 181 kg;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 10%, for a new incinerator that has a chamber capacity of 181 kg or more, assessed after the incinerator has reached its operating temperature.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who uses an incinerator must make and keep records respecting all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the type and quantity of mortalities, solid waste and semi-solid waste incinerated and the date of each incineration;
all inspections and maintenance of the incinerator;
the results of all opacity assessments conducted under section 75 (2) [disposal by incineration];
if opacity limits under section 75 (2) are exceeded,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date on which the limit was exceeded,
the level of opacity, and
the corrective action taken.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who manages, stores or uses agricultural products for the purposes of an agricultural operation must ensure that contaminated runoff, leachate and solids from the agricultural products do not enter a watercourse, cross a property boundary or go below the water table.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 264/2022, s. (a).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Treatment of contaminated runoff, leachate and wastewater

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to a person who, as part of an agricultural operation, collects and stores contaminated runoff, leachate or wastewater and treats the stored materials to remove pathogens, suspended solids, nutrients, metals and chemicals.
A person to whom this section applies and who uses an existing treatment system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may discharge the treated product to land or water,
must notify a director before February 28, 2021, that this section applies to the person, and
must provide to the director any information the director requires respecting the treatment system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person to whom this section applies and who uses a modified or new treatment system may discharge the treated product to land or water if the person does all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notifies a director at least 60 days before modifying or installing the treatment system by providing to the director

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the designs and plans for the treatment system, as prepared by a qualified professional,
the projected quality and rate of flow of the treated product, and
any further information required by the director;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: makes any changes to the designs and plans required by the director;
receives approval from the director for modification or construction of the treatment system to begin;
modifies or constructs the treatment system according to the designs and plans approved by the director;
provides the director with drawings of the treatment system, as modified or constructed, within 30 days of completing the modification or construction;
complies with the requirements and limits, if any, imposed by the director.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who must make or keep records under this code must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep the records for at least 5 years, and
submit the records to a director or an officer within 5 business days of being required by the director or officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if a director has reason to believe that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person has not complied with this code, or
taking an action referred to in this section is necessary to ensure that the purposes of this code, as stated under section 2 (1) [agricultural operations to which this code applies], are being met.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the circumstances set out in subsection (1) and without limiting the powers of a director under any other provision of this code, a director may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require a person to make or keep specified records or to provide specified information, in the form and manner required by the director;
require a person to keep the records referred to in paragraph (a) for the period specified by the director, and produce the records to the director within the time required by the director;
require assessments, tests, analysis or monitoring in respect of any activity carried out or structure or equipment used for the purposes of an agricultural operation;
require a qualified professional to conduct assessments, tests, analysis or monitoring for the purposes of paragraph (c), and to prepare a report;
specify the methodology to be used to conduct assessments, tests, analysis or monitoring for the purposes of paragraphs (c) and (d);
require a person to take corrective action if a provision of this code is contravened;

require a person who is complying with this code but whose agricultural operations are, or are likely, causing or contributing beyond a minimal extent to pollution, to take one or more actions to reduce or mitigate the effects of that pollution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For greater certainty and without limiting section 7 of the Waste Discharge Regulation, a director may impose a requirement under subsection (2) of this section that is in addition to a requirement under this code or in circumstances in which this code does not otherwise impose the requirement.
A person who is subject to a requirement under subsection (2) must comply with the requirement.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a director exercises a power under this code, the director must do so in writing and give reasons for exercising the power.
Each director must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that copies of the maps referred to in the Schedules are available

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on a website that is maintained by or on behalf of the ministry of the minister and is publicly and freely accessible, and
in the office of the administrator, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: allow members of the public to access the maps during the director's regular business hours and without charge.
